title: 108_s2154
content: The Act may be cited as the "Dru Sjodin National Sex Offender Public Database Act of 2004" or "Dru's Law". The Act, also known as "Dru's Law," defines terms related to criminal offenses against minors, minimally sufficient sexual offender registration programs, and sexually violent offenses. The Violent Offender Registration Act defines a sexually violent predator as per the Jacob Wetterling Crimes Against Children and Sexually Violent Offender Registration Act. The NSOR database is made available to the public. The Attorney General is required to make information from the National Sex Offender Registry available to the public through a public registry on the Internet. This registry allows users to find registered sex offenders living within a specified radius of a location. The information includes details on individuals convicted of offenses against minors or sexually violent crimes. The public registry for sex offenders must provide key details such as the person's name, date of birth, current address, physical description, offense details, release date, and any other relevant information as deemed appropriate by the Attorney General. SEC. 4. RELEASE OF HIGH RISK INMATES. Any State with civil commitment proceedings must notify the attorney general before releasing sexually violent predators or high-risk individuals. The attorney general will then decide whether to initiate a civil commitment proceeding. Each State is required to closely monitor released individuals. Each State must closely monitor individuals released from incarceration for at least 1 year if they are deemed sexually violent predators or at high-risk for reoffending. States have up to 3 years to comply with this requirement after the enactment of the Act. States have up to 3 years to monitor released individuals deemed sexually violent predators or high-risk for reoffending. Failure to comply results in a 25 percent funding reduction, with reallocation to compliant states. The Senate passed the bill on November 19, 2004.
